{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3345093,"name":"","username":"ambiguouskangaroo","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/e19b73/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-27T11:32:43.700Z","cooked":"

We are trying to use opencv on a usb webcam to detect notes. Is there anyway to use that without something like rasperberry pis and with just a usb cam?.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-03-27T11:32:43.700Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":115,"reads":52,"readers_count":51,"score":585.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":460318,"topic_slug":"how-to-use-opencv-with-a-usb-webcam","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64342,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-use-opencv-with-a-usb-webcam/460318/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3345100,"name":"UnofficialForth","username":"UnofficialForth","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/unofficialforth/{size}/167902_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-27T11:48:29.852Z","cooked":"

There used to be a project called GRIP that allowed for relatively easy vision to run. I don’t know if it’s still maintained, but that’s a possibility.

Is there a reason you can’t use a pi? I suggest considering getting a coprocessor like a Raspberry Pi or orange pi running PhotonVision. It’s worth the investment, and will serve you well with its pre-trained model.

In addition to what @UnofficialForth said about a co-processor or other hardware being used

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Using a Coprocessor for vision processing

Vision processing using libraries like OpenCV for recognizing field targets or game pieces can often be a CPU intensive process. Often the load isn’t too significant and the processing can easily b...

WPILib has information about reading and processing data through the Camera Server and RoboRio for some basic openCV operations

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Read and Process Video: CameraServer Class

Concepts: The cameras typically used in FRC ®(commodity USB and Ethernet cameras such as the Axis camera) offer relatively limited modes of operation. In general, they provide only a single image o...

I presume you want to run on a roboRIO. For many years the RIOs were used with NI vision and then OpenCV so it is possible. This thread has a demo program that I guess will run okay on roboRIO v2 and maybe an original roboRIO. It’s not as fancy as a neural network but it looks like it works. It’s simple enough that conversion from Python is trivial if you need another language.

GRIP, as mentioned, can help with some canned OpenCV structure but it isn’t necessary as you already have the demo program that is complete. I don’t remember GRIP having fit Ellipse but it has several basic functions that as I mentioned are already in the Python demo program.

My team used to do its own vision coding on the rios and then RPi but decided to go COTS as much as possible and now use LimeLight vision even though our programs were generally more sophisticated than LL (they took time to program).
